content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
85/100This is a really well done settlement/colony sim! The gameplay/visuals/sounds is very relaxing yet it is a challenging game that makes you think ahead and plan out your strategy. Specially when you think the game becomes to easy the game mechanics kicks in and releases a virus on the people and if not prepared half your village dies with in a year time.  I love the city/civ/colony sim genre and this is definitely a (new) favorite!This is a typical game that you plan to play for 1 hour and next time you look on the clock it's 4 hours later.  As for the amount of features and depth of the game it could have been a bit bigger. There is no upgrading of buildings, nor a research tree or other advancing options, but the features that are there are well implemented. This is not a tripple A big budget game and only created by a few people which makes it even more outstanding as it is. Love to see a sequel of this game that has more features. Oh and before I forget. The UI is just great! I wish more similar games did the UI like this!Edited: grammar

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												In Banished you take the reigns as a benevolent dictator guiding a small group of outcasts to an unknown land. You hold their very lives in your hands as they unwittingly follow your every command to build a new town in the image of a perfect socialist paradise where everyone works where they are needed until they lie in heir grave.Traders are a necessary evil at the beginning of your town's life, however once you have exploited them for their access to livestock and seed you will be able to create a self-sufficiency that will cause your people to thrive, taking what they need when they need it and being untainted by capitalism.However you must prepare yourself for tragedy of natural disasters and disease that may decimate your loyal populace. Nomads, hearing of your success will petition to join your community, should be carefully vetted lest they bring in scarlet fever, mumps, or some other abominable plague.In the end you must not be asking whether this game is good enough for you, you should be asking whether you have what it takes to lead your people to the perfect communist utopia.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Outstanding! Elegant design; simple, but in a good way. Addictive gameplay. Very well designed game. It's everything SimCity wishes it could be. I liked the fact that there is no money in the game; it's not about getting rich and piling up cash, it's about making a town that works. Very fulfilling.Some other reviewers complained that there wasn't a whole lot of content and that they got bored fast. I have no idea what they were talking about. I liked that all content is unlocked at the start. That doesn't mean you wanna build the biggest most expensive building right at the start, in fact it's not to your benefit to do that, but what that does is make the gameplay very open and non-linear. I can set my own goals and priorities. I've played 32 hrs + and still going strong, I can tell I'll do double that no problem. For the price, I think that's a great deal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Decent as a budget title if you buy it on sale; Banished provides a fair challenge at the early stages of the game when you're struggling to survive against starvation and harsh weather.Unfortunately, there is no endgame here. Once your town gets a foothold (usually about 4 hours in), there is very little that can stop it. Once you've become self-sufficient, you occasionally have to manage citizens - replacing your blacksmith when he dies of old age, for instance. Disasters are non-interactive; you usually just want for it to run its course and then rebuild whatever it damaged.That said, this is an indie title by one lone developer, and it is impressive that one person could create a moderately entertaining city builder on his own.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Banished is a fantasticly soothing experience - as long as you don't make a mistake. Although not as hard as the likes of Dwarf Fortress (I see many comparing the two) it punishes you hard for your failures. A simple shortage in tools can send you spiralling out of controll until the whole village dies of starvation. But that's exactly what makes this game so great.Graphics-wise it is no Anno but looks nice enough to not be annyoing. The music is a little artificial but not distracting. The gameplay is superb and will get you hooked for at least 40 hours. The lategame is lacking a bit in content but the developer says he will be opening the game up to mods soon so there is at least some content to be expected.All in all Banished is in no way perfect but by far the best builder game you will have played in years. I wholeheartedly recommend buying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												At the time of writing, I've played 8 hours, and so far, it's pretty damn good.I picked up the game in a flash sale, being very wary of whether it'd actually be good or not, and I can safely say, money well spent.  I'd even go to say it'd be well spent at full price.  The game's graphics are done excellently, with their only slight fault being when zoomed in fully (at which point they're still better than most 'city' builders).  So far I've only played the game on it's easiest difficulty, and so I can't say how well the game plays on harder settings, however I hope to move up soon, as I've pretty much mastered the game at the moment.How does the game function as a 'city' builder?  It doesn't, but it is a good village or small-ish town sim.  The main challenge is to stay alive, being able to produce food and firewood before it's too late.  My main problem with my first 3 attempts (which lasted 30 mins maximum) was that I was running before I could walk.  I tried to get more houses so that I could produce more, but this in turn meant I needed to produce even more, but it's easy to find your mistakes.After you finally have a 'town' that won't trip over after it's just left the front door, you're free to expand at your own will.  You could stay as a town with only 30 inhabitants building up a stockpile, however eventually the town will become too productive.  And I don't mean with resources.  From time to time you'll accidentally♥♥♥♥♥♥something up and about 10-20 people will die, rapidly and without warning, but if you play your cards right, you'll recover pretty quickly.Only problem?  Once you have sovled your seemingly unsolvable but then easily solvable crisis, you can build exciting buildings such as the town hall (which seeminly just produces graphs, because why not), or a brewery.  There's little to expand to after you've mastered your town, except pencil pushing, booze and possibly religion (in my case as overlord govenor, there is no such thing as religion, unless there's and option to add satanism simply for a laugh, which I haven't found so far). TL;DR:  Solid game, 8/10, play it at maximum speed for a challenge and only pause if you've really cocked it up.  Buy it, it's made by one guy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												No monsters. No quests. No swords. I found this game refreshing, as it manages to be fun without forcing you to fight anything. The difficulty stems entirely from within. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to try something completely different, something that not a lot of games provide. If you like one genre of game, or think that anything without action-intense combat is boring, I would not recommend this game for you.For anyone on the fence, here are some pros and cons. Everyone likes pros and cons.Pros:○ The UI is phenomenal. Some things might be a little too big or too small, but everything is pretty easy to find, and you can tell what everything is supposed to do.○ Difficulty is just customizable enough. Likewise, the difficulty curve is naturally progressing and works well.○ The game alt-tabs just fine. A minor point, but there are a surprising number of games which you just can't alt-tab out of. Banished auto-pauses you if you alt-tab.○ The graphics are, in my opinion, quite nice. The theme of the game comes through very strongly through the graphical style used.Cons:○ The game is relatively slow-paced, and it can take a long time to get anywhere.○ Not a lot of content at this time, so it's a long game with few options. Can get boring if you manage to stabilize a village.○ Villagers are sometimes really stupid. Not dwarf stupid, but pretty stupid.Other Points:○ No game over screen when things spiral completely out of control and you're left with no citizens and no way to get more citizens. Just a small quirk. Not good or bad, really. I kinda like it: you get to watch as your village is slowly consumed by nature once more.

Building, planning, farming, trading, resource gathering, expansion, seasons to prepare for, and more.  If you like city builders, then this is one game you must have.  I do hope that there are more expansion updates in the future, and if there are, these will only add to the fantastic offering already on the plate.Buy, play and enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Tons of fun. I was initially a bit hesitent to get the game after seeing some reviewers going off about how difficult/impossible the game is, but I'm so glad I bought it. It's not as difficult/impossible as some reviewers would have you believe, especially if you do a little basic strategy research beforehand. With that, my FIRST town reached a population of ~450 before finally collapsing due to mistakes on my part (a massive food distribution problem during a famine). I've started over from scratch and I expect my next town to be even bigger and better now that I understand the game mechanics better this time around. Yes, the game can be difficult and has a bit of a learning curve, but that doesn't make it as difficult/impossible as a lot of disgruntled reviewers would have you believe. (Tip: Stick to hunting/gathering/fishing early on! Only start planting crops for farming when you have a stable food supply and a surplus of food and labor! This is almost all you need to know to get off to a good start!) If you like city-builders and you have the small amount of patience required to learn how to play the game properly, you will love it and wonder what happened to your weekend. My only criticism so far is that I would like to see some more features eventually - for example, a way to slightly alter terrain. We don't need to have the ability to move mountains, but it's annoying when you can't put down a 15x15 crop field because ONE tile inside the area is too "uneven." Also, ridges that are too uneven to build roads over and too shallow to build tunnels through, yet that people are able to walk over, are annoying. It would also be fun to eventually see some new crops, livestock, jobs, resources, etc. The game is already a blast, but also has a LOT of potential.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												Banished is a great citybuilding singleplayer game that finally revives the genre.The mechanics, a very important thing for citybuilders are easy to learn and very well polished.The AI is smart and can survive without you as well. Does this mean the game gets boring once your village can sustain?No it doesn't! Even though your peopl can survive without you for quite some time, you will ALWAYS find something else to do in this amazing piece of art. Be it expanding, finding just another resource you could gather somewhere on those gigantic maps or just managing your trade depot because you want all those different kinds of seeds so bad!The game comes with a great set of Jobs, buildings and fun things to do so it will never get boring.Oh, and lets not forget those disasters! (Which you can disable) You think your whole town is good to go and some tornado basically kills half your population.Also, there will eventually be a great modkit that, together with a very loving community, will give loads of new and free content as well.So if you love managing cities, looking at loving art and watching people live their colony life, this game is a must! But I gotta warn you: It's addictive!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This game is a masterpiece.  It may appear simple at first glance, but that is a deception.  The music is relaxing, and the graphics are surprisingly decent for a one-man development team.  The largest map size blows SimCity out of the water.  More importantly, each town's history can easily  become a rich and unforgettable story of struggle, triumph, and even horror.My first attempt at city-building reminded me of something out of Kentucky where, after a particularly harsh winter, all but 2 old men and a little girl had died of starvation.  I  literally cheered when the little girl hit the magical age of consent (10), married her old neighbor, and started popping out new laborers.. er kids.  And then the incest really began.  In my second attempt, I watched helplessly as a tornado ravaged my little citizens, tearing down trees and houses alike.  Within a year, the surviors had successfully rebuilt most of their little paradise only for a  second tornado to wipe out all but a brother and sister.  Not even incest could save them.Someday, I will have a glorious tale to tell of a village that evolved into a sprawling landscape of commerce and booze... a land where brother and sister need not contemplate the survival of their people through sinister acts... For a mere $20, you can too.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This is a fun village builder but it does lack some big features. I just noticed that I've spent 23 hours playing this game since getting it earlier in the week. For now, it manages to overcome it's weaknesses but I'd love to see some improvements. What I like: Runs great on dated hardware. All the time I've put in this game was done on a 6 y/o laptop.Difficulty modes only impact what you start with in the game. So whichever you chose, you're still playing the same game. Plenty of buildings all available right away. Some buildings are useless until you get other supplies. Several ways to gather resources. You can gather what's around you or build something to produce what you need. Controls. Moving around the map and laying stuff down is easy. Overall fun gameplay. It wouldn't be any good if the gameplay wasn't solid. What I dislike: No tech upgrades. I don't call this a city builder because it doesn't feel like a city... just a big village. The only upgrades I've noticed are stone roads, stone houses, steel tools, and warmer jackets. Limited resources. Iron and stone are the most limited. There's only so many quarries / mines a map can handle. Limited water buildings. You can't build a port for your own fisherman to go on lakes so all fishing is from the docks. This makes larger bodies of water nothing more than an inconvenience.Repetitive gameplay. Once you get in the flow, it's easy to just do the same thing over and over to expand and be successful. I enjoy the game and I'd say it's worth a try. The limitations of a 1 man dev team do show; however, considering that it's a 1 man dev team, it's very impressive how good the game is.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												I have bought this game on release because im interested in this genre.This is not a casual game and requires great patience and skill.Lets got through pros and contras.+ Offers random map generation (seed, size, type, difficutly etc.)+ Challenging (hard to master, i failed about 15 attempts before my city could get stable and healthy/happy)+ Deep simulation system (unlike other city builders, peoples age/gender plays a great role, family is a core unit,    people dont spawn randomly, they can only be born as kids and then age into students/workers, later on you can invite    nomads into your village)+ Original gameplay (different from anno/simcity, requires micro'ing, resource system)- Contains lots of bugs (savegame crash, some buildings texture bugs, trading doc bug etc.)- Doesnt support DX11 properly (switching to DX9 will avoid lots of crashes)I think this game will provide simulation fans with many-many hours of fun. Although the crashes are annoying and ruine this fun. I recommend to pay attention to forums before u give out 18 Euro.Once most of the major bugs (savegame/trading ship) are fixed, this game will turn into a candy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												City-building in micro form: build a small town out of nothing. Workers are born, grow up and die within your settlement, making this one of the few games where managing population strata is important. The balancing of resources is superb - there are only a few raw ingredients, the gathering of which requires significant manpower. It also involves some rather nuanced feedback loops. But despite the amount of balancing to be done, there are few games as relaxing to play. Wonderful game in the vein of Settlers (sans combat) - highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Patience. Once you establish the basics, the game will teach you patience. Ambition will punish, and time will not allow you to stand still.Banished establishes a high difficulty curve from the start. As a fairly technical city-building game, this might be welcome. For those looking for a simplistic game, this shouldn't be for you. Nonetheless, a light difficulty and disaster toggle might allow the more casual experience to have some fun. Development expects to implement modding later, but at the moment, the game is still working out some late-development bugs and compatibility issues. Read the latest news to know if you're able to run it on your machine.The game's technical approach is considerably difficult to learn, but the advanced techniques it allows means you and try to establish your own goals, or you can quickly adapt after a sudden disaster.Disappointed with the mess that was "that other city-building game that had umpteen bajillion problems"? This is less than half the cost, twice the fun, and a fraction of the unplayability issues, if any.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I have racked up over 70 hours of game play and I have to say that this game is positively wonderful. It is a wonderful de-stress (unless your villages is in the grips of calmity)...First thing right off the bat this is a city builder game that is similar to the old Windows Sid Myer's Sim City game but, in a medieval setting. There is no goal, no competition between rival towns or other players. Just you, your villagers, and a wide expanse of wilderness just waiting to be tame. And with the difficulty of the game able to adjusted to your style and desire of play and random seed map genrator not two plays are ever the same. It is a great way to relax and relish in the joys of creating, it is completely open -ended and was one of the first games I purchased on Steam a couple years back. It was in early access when I purchased it and it was one of the best risks I took. My friend who I had shown it to was hesitant to recommend buying it because it was early access but, forgive him he has been badly burned by a number of Early Access games before. However shortly after I purchased it and we sat down to play it I fell in love with this game, and he did too (litterally buying within the hour after we stoped playing). This game is one of only five that have made it into my Favorites listing which say alot as I don't add games to find them easier it is a honest to goodness favorite game of mine. The game has only gotten better and the developer has always been diligent in bug fixing and maintenance.I highly recommend this game, it is great for say a college student who doesn't get a whole lot of time to play but, wants something fun. Another plus to this game is if you grew up like I did playing the orginal Sim City game then you will like this game its a wonderful reminder of childhood for me.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Think of Settlers combined with Tropico without an economy and without armies - and you get Banished, but without the DRM, required signups and always online requirement that the latter mentioned games have.  Banished is a simple game, weighing in at a quarter of a gigabyte in size - yet it can provide many hours of entertainment with its challenging obstacles and everchanging environment.This is city building and management at its finest.  It's like Star Trek - everybody gets a job to do, nobody gets paid.  If you don't pull your weight, you die.  Nobody complains about wages, the jobs they have to do - they just get on with it, like good Amish people without the hats.After 100 hours gameplay, I'm happy to say that this is one of the most rewarding games I've played for the price tag.  Kudos to the sole developer, and I wish you much luck with your future endeavours.  May you be this decade's Chris Sawyer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												CTD and RepetitiveFIRST THE CRASH TO DESKTOP ISSUE:  My first play session worked fine, except the menu was too small for my resolution (1920 x 1080).  A few adjustments in the settings fixed that.  However, during my second play session the game would crash after about 5 minutes of play time.  (For reference, I’m running this on Windows 8.1, 64 bit)  After some research, I finally discovered a fix which involved going into the registry and deleting some entries.  And I discovered this fix only worked as long as you didn’t start a new game.  If you did, you’d have to edit the registry again.  This is certainly something a player should not have to do in order to get a working game.ON TO THE PLAYING:  So I bought the game because it seemed fun.  I generally like resource management and time management games.  I've played Sims, SimCity, Diner Dash, Cooking Dash, etc. just to give you an idea.At first it was fun.  I could place buildings where I wanted.  A few like the houses even had different styles to choose from by typing the "F" key before placing it on the ground.  I liked watching my little worker ants hurry around.  I quickly got a handle on my food supply, and this was despite some of the workers hoarding a disproportionate amount of food in their houses which meant less for others.  It’s not that hard really.  Just have some farm fields during the growing season, and you also have a few hunters, fishermen, and/or gatherers.  I also got control of wood, stone, etc.In the end, it seemed all I needed to do was sit with the workers pane open and subtract or add workers to different positions as I needed.  For example: “Subtract 3 workers from Gathering, and add those 3 to Building because I have a wave of construction projects going on.”  It’s just a matter of clicking up or down on the arrows next to the jobs in the list.  I just needed to do that and keep an eye on the resource panes.  That’s why it got repetitive, and I played less than 10 hours.  Maybe that’s all the game is really meant for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												No monsters. No quests. No swords. I found this game refreshing, as it manages to be fun without forcing you to fight anything. The difficulty stems entirely from within. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to try something completely different, something that not a lot of games provide. If you like one genre of game, or think that anything without action-intense combat is boring, I would not recommend this game for you.For anyone on the fence, here are some pros and cons. Everyone likes pros and cons.Pros:○ The UI is phenomenal. Some things might be a little too big or too small, but everything is pretty easy to find, and you can tell what everything is supposed to do.○ Difficulty is just customizable enough. Likewise, the difficulty curve is naturally progressing and works well.○ The game alt-tabs just fine. A minor point, but there are a surprising number of games which you just can't alt-tab out of. Banished auto-pauses you if you alt-tab.○ The graphics are, in my opinion, quite nice. The theme of the game comes through very strongly through the graphical style used.Cons:○ The game is relatively slow-paced, and it can take a long time to get anywhere.○ Not a lot of content at this time, so it's a long game with few options. Can get boring if you manage to stabilize a village.○ Villagers are sometimes really stupid. Not dwarf stupid, but pretty stupid.Other Points:○ No game over screen when things spiral completely out of control and you're left with no citizens and no way to get more citizens. Just a small quirk. Not good or bad, really. I kinda like it: you get to watch as your village is slowly consumed by nature once more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I have never had any inclination to ever review a game before - but this game is just simply blissful elegance to play.  I would strongly recommend purchasing this game if you are inclined towards RTS/City Building games.  The experience of this game is more enjoyable then any game to come out recently with huge development teams - but to learn that this was created by one man (Luke) is incredible.  However there are some flaws (which I am sure will be addressed soon).  The flaws I have found:Game has a tendency to suffer fatal errors in a variety of scenarios (upon save, upon different common in game actions).  I have yet to get a population above 400 - not because of my city building ability but because I have had 3 or 4 games where the game crashes and I cannot alter my play state to avoid the error.  I am not overly disappointed in this because after browsing the forum - it looks like the developer is taking a very proactive role in correcting the issues. (My Rig - Windows 7 64 bit SLI SDD).The game lacks what, to me, would be a real end goal and after a while it fills like your building small towns that work together within the map then one homogenous city.  Beyond the basic buildings I have found nothing to unlock besides Steam achievements which don't do too much to get me excited.  However - I feel like this will probably be addressed by Luke or by the modding community when the tools are eventually released.  However - on the flip side - the simplicity also adds to the beauty of the game in a way.  I could see this game getting monotonous - especially to someone who requires in your face action or war type scenarios.  I think with about 50 hours (assuming the bugs are fixed) I will have seen everything this game has to offer at this point.One thing I have really enjoyed about the game is its difficulty.  The first 4 or 5 times I played I failed miserably quickly in to the game.  The frustrations of watching all your citizens die one by one is painful and frustrating.  This is not a bad thing though - it is one of the most enjoyable parts of the game - learning from your mistakes and using foresight the next time to prevent the issues from happening again.  It's also great to know that if you are not on top of your game at any given time - 5 min later you could see your town falter and everything you worked for fall like dominoes.So summation - at full price in its current state - it would be a hard sell for me.  For $20.00 - you should buy it as long as you are aware of the flaws and have some patients during the meantime for the bugs to be worked out.  If you do wish to wait - make sure to come back eventually because this game is amazing.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Banished is a unique and somewhat unforgiving take on the city building genre. The game puts you in charge of a small colony of people that have just arrived in a strange, (and randomly generated), land. The game requires you to make sure your people are fed, have housing (and warmth!), tools, and clothes to survive with. On the surface it seems very much like your typical sim...where the difference lies is the difficulty! If you react too soon to a problem - you spread your self too thin and you limit your growth. Do it too late and you do not have time to adjust. For example: waiting until your almost out of food to build more farms..by the time the crops are planted and harvested (which take an entire season in game). Your people will have already started to die off. The game can be hard..but it also has a very rewarding feeling when you manage to grow your little hamlet of 20 people to a sprawling town of 500+. If your looking for a more serious take on a sim game I say give this one a try. Just be ready to watch your people freeze/starve/be crushed by rocks/eaten by boars for your first few games. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Excellent game.Not every builder needs to turn into another combat game, which is apparently a rule for most designers.  Apparently it's too tough to make a game interesting without weapons.  Sometimes its challenging just keeping people alive, well fed and warm.  An early frost can be just as deadly as a zerg rush.  There's a lot here to keep you busy, and enough variation to keep you occupied a long time.  If you have any interest in city builders, this is for you.I have to say that I love the negative reviewer who thinks every building is required to produce the exact same amount every year.  Genius!  Because that's how life in the wilderness works, right?   I can still hear my great great great garndfather saying "we were 200 corn short last year.  I told you that field should have been 12x12 not 10x10."I do wish you could choose a bit more about your start possessions, or at least have a random button.  But with a game like this there will always be more you'd like to add, and I haven't spent long yet browsing the mods.  If you like builders, buy this now.  Or check out some Let's Plays if you're not sure (Quill18 has a couple good ones).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Addicting and challenging "city" builder. The term "city builder" is used loosely here as even at the largest, the towns created in here aspire to "large medieval hamlet". This game distinguishes itself from other city builders in two respects. First, it is difficult; almost punishingly difficult. This is especially true if you are used to more forgiving city builder sims, where the tide of the game can be shifted with an ordinance, a building, or a tax hike. There are no such instruments in Banished. Build too many houses, a season later there are hungry mouths to feed with not enough workers to provide food. Build too slowly, and the aging population is unable to replace workers fast enough. Each decision needs to be made with the consequences of the future in mind, as the impact of a single building can have a ripple effect seasons later. Second, unlike many other city builders there are not a plethora of buildings, and no direction towards the "You Win" building. All buildings and upgrades are available from the word go. The exercise of Banished is one of a balancing act, rather than a sprint. The player must keep food, population, and resources in perfect balance or a death spiral can very rapidly occur. It can lead to some frustration early on, but the best advice that can be given is not to get too attached to the first town that one builds. However, as the mechanics become more and more apparent, a rhythm to the gameplay will emerge and that is when Banished truly hooks the player.The game gets a recommendation for players who long for a city builder with some serious depth despite the bucolic exterior. If someone is looking for a game with a campaign to lead them through a series of missions and hand hold through each step of the way, look elsewhere. While there is a tutorial, it only covers the very basic mechanics, it leaves the rest to the player.

Once your town gets a foothold (usually about 4 hours in), there is very little that can stop it. Once you've become self-sufficient, you occasionally have to manage citizens - replacing your blacksmith when he dies of old age, for instance. Disasters are non-interactive; you usually just want for it to run its course and then rebuild whatever it damaged.That said, this is an indie title by one lone developer, and it is impressive that one person could create a moderately entertaining city builder on his own.

												Outright this game is very enjoyable. On the other hand, you start encountering little gripes like "Why are my villagers so damn dumb?  Use the roads I built you fools!" or "Why are workers carrying stuff to the storages on the opposite end of the map when there none of the others are full?"  However, this is a great problem to have in general as it gives some indication of direction for later efforts (both by community and dev).Very recommended for people like me who can spend an entire weekend day playing and even for those with busy daily lives who may not be able to dedicate more than maybe an hour in a sitting.  The really hard part for both types of players is prying yourself away from it to do things that are necessary...like eating and sleeping.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Banished is a game goes back to the roots for people who enjoy City Builder games. It's pretty simple in it's setup, yet has some incredible dept that sucks you in and gives you hours and hours of entertainment.For me personally this game really reminds me of the older simcities, back when there was much less handholding. As I said the strenght of this game is in the challanging mechanics below the seemingly easy exterior. The whole game is a well executed balance game, where most action have certain consequences. Unlike a lot of other city builder games as of late (including for example the latest version of Simcity), where the games are generally more forgiving when taking a sub-optimal route.A good example is the balance that comes with expanding your population. In Banished it's not as easy as just putting down a few extra houses. Sure this will increase your population, but if you have to keep in mind the increase in resource consumed (essential ones like food, but also secondary resources like firewood). On the other hand not expanding your population quickly enough could mean you run into the problem of having too many people die of old age which will cut hard into your workforce.The only negative I can probably note about this game is that at a certain point it will start lacking a bit of repeatability. Once you get the hang of the balance game and get good at setting up efficient supply chains, expanding your towns is mostly a rince and repeat activity. And because this is a pure city builder game to the core, there are no other "objectives" to keep you busy. On the plus side, this game is still fully in development so we might expect to see some decent additions.(TL;DR)All in all Banished is a game that will keep you busy for quite a while, making it more than worth the price. It goes back to the roots of City Builder games and it's simple setup with some challanging mechanics will keep you entertained whether you're new to the genre or a veteran.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												BanishedBanished is a sort of Civilisation, or City Simulator based in the past, where the general theme is to expand your town/city while managing your resources and citizens closely.Visually I find this game very pleasing. The trees, water and even rocks look very nice, and the animations are also done well. There isn’t a huge amount to say about the audio, but it does the job. 	The game itself is hard to talk about. You start with a small number of villagers, and have to have them collect resources such as wood, stone, and food, while building new houses for them to live in. Houses allow your population to grow, giving you more children, which eventually will become adults and workers. That all sounds fairly standard, and even simplistic, but do not be fooled; this game can destroy you. That may sound somewhat strange, when you consider the fact there are no roaming barbarians, vicious animals, or in fact any enemies at all. No, the difficulty is the extent of micro management that is required to keep your town functioning. It’s about finding balance. You might want to build several houses for your villagers, so they can sleep, and take shelter from the weather. That’s all well and good, but that one simple choice now has several consequences such as the need for more wood to be converted to firewood to keep the people warm, it will also increase the population as people start to have children. More children will eventually mean more workers, but in the short term they’re just more mouths to consume precious food. You also have to consider the materials used for the house, and how many people you assign to build it, will no longer be collecting those resources for the time it takes to build. This is just one example, but that is the kind of thing that makes it what it is. Every choice has to be thought through, even the positioning of the houses. A house too far away from the occupants work area means less efficiency and less resources gathered. 	Your citizens will need to be closely monitored, as they have general health, which can be maintained with a Herbalist making remedies, happiness which is very hard to manage, but can be helped with buildings like Taverns, and Hunger needs to be monitored so they don’t starve to death. Interestingly your citizens will grow old, and they will die of old age, which is an easy thing to forget, and if you do, you may end up with a very old town, incapable of having children, and so you lose by attrition. Weather affects them too, meaning you need to make some warm clothes for winter, and light for summer, and maintain a steady supply of tools for people to actually do their jobs with. 	Overall the mechanics are very solid and are easy to understand, but difficult to master. However, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows for the game, unfortunately. The pacing of the game can be extremely slow, even when you manually adjust the timer to the fastest setting. Some of the controls, like having someone stop their current job and start doing something else (or work somewhere else) seems very much in the hands of the AI. Sometimes people just won’t do what you want. The biggest thing with Banished though, is ‘the point’. As in ‘what’s the point?’. Truth be told, there isn’t one. There are no technologies to advance, no enemies to conquer, no end of the game or unlocks. You simply just go until you fill the map (which looks quite small). Now, I appreciate that not all games have ‘a point’ per se (ex: Minecraft, Space Engineers, Garry’s Mod) but the majority do, and the ones that don’t are usually based on the player creating something unique, and are multiplayer. Banished has none of those features. Conclusion; to wrap it up I’d say that Banished is a well made and balanced game, with an emphasis on resource and micro-management in a slow paced environment. A recommendation really depends on the person considering buying the game. If you’re the sort of person that likes to pick up a game, play it from start to finish and put it down for a while, this game is likely not for you, so avoid it at all costs. However, if you’re the sort of person that likes a nice, slow paced game, with heavy man-management systems and are not too bothered by campaigns or story driven games, then this is right up your street.Assuming you’re the latter category, I’d give it 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game is amazing! I'm going to let you know right from start that this game will be challenging. I've had a couple cities perish until I finally found good balances for resources. The music, the graphics, the tiny little details for the villagers' daily lives that go on in the game are wonderful. The game is just a blast to play. While you might think "What if I want to eventually fight something?" you're not going to have time to think that because you'll be more concerned about how you're going to keep your food storage constant enough to maintain your villigers during the winter.Gaming Tips:I personally recommend building a fishing dock first thing when you start unless you're not near water, then I would go for the hunter's cabin instead. I also play on 5x speed but that is also up to you. Just make sure you have firewood and food for when winter comes because a lot of times the first winter makes or breaks a village. And with crop fields, Have your farmers there at early spring, then once the fields have been harvested (usually sometime in autum, it depends) then have them work on other things in the village so they won't be wasting their time until early spring returns (or if the snow thaws in late winter)I can say that this game will be eating up many hours of free time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Banished is a primitive, (maybe a bit too primitive) yet beautiful city simulation.I rate this game a solid 7/10This game is a game that can be played for hours on end.Pros: Lots of automated things, you don't have to assign people to houses, they just find a house and live in it. Very easy to use user interface. You can have a ton of cities at once. It's one of those games that you can play for hours on end, just evolving and growing your city.Cons: Sometimes a bit difficult even on Easy mode. Very bare-bones style. It seems as though that all you do is make sure people live, and that's about it. Graphics should be better. (Games like this rarely have good graphics, so I can't blame it.) Wish I could zoom in just a bit more. Sometimes there's nothing you can do, and you just have to watch your city die and start all over again, which is one of the worst things to happen.How it could improve: Fix all of the cons. (Obviously) You should be able to change things a bit more. (Upgrade houses and things like fishing docks and wood cutters, build boats to fish from, etc.) I'd like to be able to get close to the characters and hear them speaking. I'd like to tap in to peoples lives, just to make the game a little more immersive.Conclusion:All in all, I enjoy the game and have played for hours on end. I'd say that it's well worth $20.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												One of the best city building sims I've ever played. It seems, almost, too simple of a game...build farms, cut down trees, chip away at the stone, hunt some deer etc. Then, all of a sudden, your tools are broken, so you cannot harvest wood for warmth, cannot break stone or mine iron to make new tools, and then your townsfolk start dying off....So, be prepared to start over, chances are your town will die off (due to starvation, lack of warmth, population has stopped growing, or simply due to illness). The replayability is decent enough, so starting over isn't a huge deal, and it has a learning curve (esecially the larger settlements).The mod support adds so much to the vanilla game (Though I suggest starting off with the core game, as some mods can seem overwhelming to a beginner).All in all, I highly suggest this game (especially if you enjoy this genre). I got it on sale, I suggest you do too (Let's face it, most of us get our games this way)

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
85/100This is a really well done settlement/colony sim! The gameplay/visuals/sounds is very relaxing yet it is a challenging game that makes you think ahead and plan out your strategy. Specially when you think the game becomes to easy the game mechanics kicks in and releases a virus on the people and if not prepared half your village dies with in a year time.  I love the city/civ/colony sim genre and this is definitely a (new) favorite!This is a typical game that you plan to play for 1 hour and next time you look on the clock it's 4 hours later.  As for the amount of features and depth of the game it could have been a bit bigger. There is no upgrading of buildings, nor a research tree or other advancing options, but the features that are there are well implemented. This is not a tripple A big budget game and only created by a few people which makes it even more outstanding as it is. Love to see a sequel of this game that has more features. Oh and before I forget. The UI is just great! I wish more similar games did the UI like this!Edited: grammar

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												It may look a little difficult at first, but once you figure the basics out, it's very easy to make progress. You have difficulty settings, too, so if you prefer a relaxing game or want to learn without stress, you have the option. On the other hand, if you love challenges, you can have them (and they can be pretty harsh!)The UI is fantastic, you can choose to display or hide as much as you prefer. The AI is very good, the mechanics are tough but fair, and learning them feels truly rewarding.I've found that, in longer games, I end up a bit bored, but only because I don't dare continue making my town bigger. I have yet to create a proper city (I just love tiny cute towns so much)I think Banished is an excellent game for fans of classic strategy and city building/management, but also a great starting point for someone new to the genre. If you've never played strategy but want to try it, Banished is a great candidate for it. I definitely recommend it.

Use the roads I built you fools!" or "Why are workers carrying stuff to the storages on the opposite end of the map when there none of the others are full?"  However, this is a great problem to have in general as it gives some indication of direction for later efforts (both by community and dev).Very recommended for people like me who can spend an entire weekend day playing and even for those with busy daily lives who may not be able to dedicate more than maybe an hour in a sitting.  The really hard part for both types of players is prying yourself away from it to do things that are necessary...like eating and sleeping.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Its a survival city building game.  It takes its inspiration from games like Dwarf Fortress, Towns, and Gnomoria.  Dwarf Fortress being the most complex of them, and the others being very derivative and simpler.  Banished is definitely the simplest and least complex of them all.  However that doesn't really detract from the fun of trying to survive in the harsh land you have been dropped into.  Double however, once you have figured out how to strike a balance with your world and have grown it out there is little more to do, due to the lack of content and end game goals.  And there aren't many mods that add anything terribly interesting to the game.  Much of them are little tweaks to annoying aspects of the game or aesthetic tweaks.  But until then you will find the game challenging and fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Banished is an outstanding achievement for a one man team. The game has very complex mechanics that reward the player that experiments with the environment of the game. This even though everything is very well explained at the beginning, at least the basics. The tutorials are clear and well made, short but not so to skip anything important that the beginner needs to know. I managed to make a village of 500 people in 7-8 hours of gameplay. However to achieve this village I dumped two villages for a total of 42h of gameplay. It has high replayability value, with different terrains conditions and seeds, try different resource gathering strategies, or different town layouts. I feel I beat the game (I will truly beat it when I get 900+ villagers) but nonetheless I am curious about what other possible strategies there are to achieve a 300+ pop. An example of other gathering strategies, build a lot of woodcutters and build many tradeposts, then buy stone and iron with the surplus of fuel. This way you don't need any mines or quarries. Make a lot of hunters and pastures with cattle, to get a surplus of leather, then make a few tailors, get a surplus of coats and sell them for food + stone + iron + coal. etc... etc...I have recommended very few games but this one deserves it. Go on and read the bad reviews, you will see most of them haven't played the game more than 20h or haven't achieved 300+ pop. They say wether that it's too easy or that it's too hard, if they say it's too easy it is because it is easy... at the beginning at least. After the 300 threshold it gets pretty challenging to coordinate supplies and the time the villagers take to get to houses from workplaces to avoid a deathmarch. Anyway, buy this game, for the sake of the developer and for a bug free release (yes, bug free!).Hugs :D

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I've played though all difficulties and came up with this information:Easy if you would like to figure out the extent of the game and to have fun without worry.Medium, you'll have a challenge to build houses at first, but it's not so bad when you get enough food.Hard if you want a real challenge, also add in some random events for fun. You'll have a hard time and may fail right away if you don't understand the way this game is played.Tips/Spoiler: Center town plus North, East, West, South stockpiles and stores with gatherers and hunters out there. Add a market to the center to cover the four areas and work from there. If you're playing the harder than easy difficulties, you're on your own but I will leave you with this: Time is on your side only if you can manage it, so take care of the speed system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												This game is so damn hard! You think you are doing well and then you notice that your citizens have no food and then half of them are dead, literally. However, the feeling you get when you overcome these challenges, at least temporarily, is immense.There will always be a struggle for resources, whether it be food, clothes or building materials and it isn't a simple case of mining what you need or whatever the case may be. You need to have citizens to be available to do these tasks, if there are none then what you want done will not be done.There are a couple of things that aren't quite right, such as people forever switching jobs with each other whenever they please and builders taking the long route to build a bridge, but that doesn't make it a bad game, in fact it's quite the opposite.This game involves no fighting against other people or anything like that, it's all about building a town, with people who were banished from somewhere, and managing to get it to survive against the harsh reality of nature and prosper.It is no simple task.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Simply put, Banished is a town builder where the goal is to have your village thrive. It's The Oregon Trail meets Sim City. From a handful of families to hundreds of people, you re-create how the ancient settlements of a few people became the burgeoning cities of today. The game itself has a few simple mechanics and a very stripped down UI which can be viewed in individual parts. The graphics are acceptable (nothing too amazing), and the controls are intuitive. It may not be your cup of tea as there is no win condition and there's no real economy building, so if you are interested, take a look at some game play videos which go over the game as they help illustrate how the game is played and how it feels.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												A great city-building game. I love the atmosphere and scenery of the game, and the relaxing music makes this a very chill experience (punctuated by the first frantic winters of scrambling to get enough food and firewood of course). It is in many ways something of a puzzle-game combined with a city-builder though, because like a good puzzle game, once you’ve found the optimal placement of buildings and such, the game doesn’t really introduce anything new, and instead can get a bit dull.Overall, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who likes a good puzzle game or city-builder. I would simply say not to play this expecting some big grand city-building experience—there are no bandits to raid your outlying villages, no avalanches or floods to wash away massive sections of your town certain times of year (though there are occasional tornados and a few other minor events). It is good for what it does, just don’t expect it to be bigger or grander than what it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Banished is a unique and somewhat unforgiving take on the city building genre. The game puts you in charge of a small colony of people that have just arrived in a strange, (and randomly generated), land. The game requires you to make sure your people are fed, have housing (and warmth!), tools, and clothes to survive with. On the surface it seems very much like your typical sim...where the difference lies is the difficulty! If you react too soon to a problem - you spread your self too thin and you limit your growth. Do it too late and you do not have time to adjust. For example: waiting until your almost out of food to build more farms..by the time the crops are planted and harvested (which take an entire season in game). Your people will have already started to die off. The game can be hard..but it also has a very rewarding feeling when you manage to grow your little hamlet of 20 people to a sprawling town of 500+. If your looking for a more serious take on a sim game I say give this one a try. Just be ready to watch your people freeze/starve/be crushed by rocks/eaten by boars for your first few games. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												A great RTS and survival game that offers addictive fun as well as rather complex and unforgiving challenges to face that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The best micromanaging simulator I've ever played so far!Imagine starting with a population of 12 and then losing 8 of them because you couldn't gather enough food in time before they starved. Now it is down to 3 guys and 1 woman to repopulate the whole town. And when you got back on your feet with everything you need (ex. population of 18, farmlands, schoolhouse, etc), oh no a big tornado decides to steam roll through your town destroying your schoolhouse, killing all the small children and most of your workers in the process :( Now down to a Pop of 3 and all over the age of 55, you make more kids somehow and send all your kids at the age of 10 to go work in the mines or become the town doctor (way cooler than being a pokemon trainer, amiright?) Only Con: I'll never understand why 85 year olds will continue being a lumberjack, 10 year olds becoming blacksmiths, or how in the "20 years" my town exists in-game that you will have citizens that will be born there and will die at the age of 90. In all honesty, this doesn't ruin the game at all for me but I do find it hilarious watching an extremely healthy and happy person die of old age at 65 while the very unhealthy and most depressed person ever will live to 89 (cause of death: A rock in the quarry fell on him). 10/10 would run town into ground again

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Libertie spent all day, every day, collecting food for the rest of the village. She worked until her fingers were numb and bleeding, but never ceased in her quest to provide for the other townsfolk. When the food began to run out, Libertie worked even harder, foregoing her own meals in order to provide more and more for the older and younger members of her fledgeling community. Libertie worked harder and harder, and got thinner and thinner, starving herself in order to put more food into the mouths of others. Then, one day, out in the forest with no-one but the birds to witness her selfless work, Libertie's body simply gave up. She died of starvation, while gathering food.10/10Will play again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Having played a good few hours of Banished so far, I've got to say: this is a good game. Not great, but good. Overall, my impression is that it's still very much a work in progress.Banished draws you in and easily sucks away hours of your life as you concern yourself with keeping your villagers alive and building them a stable and, above all, sustainable home. There is a real sense of accomplishment in transforming three families and a cartload of basic supplies into a thriving community of hundreds of villagers.However, a few times now I have got to the point where it seems I have achieved all I can in the game. Others who have played Banished might recognise it; you have built up most of the viable land on the map, stabilised your population, and backed it all up with a steady supply of food and resources. What is there left to do? Apart from sitting behind your monitor and appreciating all that you've built, honestly, not much...Once you have built all the 'civic' buildings (which can occur relatively early on) there is little left to achieve besides marginally increasing the population. That gets old rather quickly. There is the odd 'disaster' which occurs, but there is little you can do to directly combat those. Instead, you simply wait for them to run their course and rebuild, if necessary. I feel Banished is crying out for a deeper level of complexity in order to increase its replay value. Building up larger communities should come with the societal problems which typically arise from them. I once saw one of my villagers met his end because he was "stabbed". An incident like that should trigger an event which leads to your society choosing its own justice system. And why don't the citizens protest after a stonecutter has been crushed by a rock for the umpteenth time? Those feel like missed opportunities to me.In short, I feel that with a game like this you should be able to eventually control its society and politics a bit more to give each settlement its own 'flavour'. I'll be keeping a keen eye on the future development of this game in the hope something like that will be added.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This game is really fun. I thought that it would be stressful and all of my people would die. I am happy to say I have only had 6 deaths. Only because one family was greedy and took all the food. The game is sort of simple to learn. The only hard part to the game is keeping everyone alive for the first few years. I am currently on year 8 and have had to build 2 storage houses to store all my food.The basic movement and placement controls are nice and simple. The game runs really smooth, never have an issue with choppy FPS or anything along those lines (running on high graphics). I like that they kept the camera controls to the WASD instead of the arrow keys. The only thing I don't like is trying to remember what keys do what for the tool bar. Kind of wish they wouldn't have used the function keys but that is my view and I could just change them in options. Other than that, I think the controls are great and user friendly.I think the graphics could have been a little better. I feel like I am playing a more economy based StrongHold 2. On the flip side I like having the graphics like that because older computers can play the game as well.I like the idea of having mods. I know that they just updated the game to allow mods so I don't expect to much yet. From what I have used, most work while others don't. I do look forward to seeing more building types thought. I think by having mods we are able to build our towns/cities better.Over all rating: 9/10Gameplay: 10/10Graphics: 8/10Controls: 9/10Replay Value: 10/10Mods: 7/10

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												This is an excelent game in it's current state, but it could be SO much more.  When I was younger, my mother played a game called "Zeus", an ancient egyptian city builder.  It played a lot like this, (in a much lower res, of course), but it had a much vaster and more interactive world.  The game evolved as you played it more and more.  With Banished, I'm able to play it for several hours at a time, but once I've got a thriving population, and collected all the seeds and animals I needed, there was nothing more to do.  You're stuck in time, unable to move forward and advance your city, there's no inovation.  The game looks great, and plays great for several hours, for the $20 price mark, it's worth it, in my opinion, but there just needs to be an expansion, an official expansion, that brings your city forward.  My personal opinion?  Have new buildings that unlock as the years go by, events that occur within the game, (inventions, discoveries, etc.), and make it a city builder that people will remember for years.  One massive expansion, and this game would be EVERYTHING i've wanted it to be.  7/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												This is a very solid singleplayer city-builder. I have not played many other city builders simply because the blocky graphics (who wants to build something if it's going to make their eyes hurt?), or way too intensive micromanaging turned me off.This game is simple. This game is easy. This game is elegant with a beautiful soundtrack. That is until a single fire ravages through your urban center destroying any sense of unity your village had. Then---DEATH SPIRAL. Death spirals are so intense, as you watch graveyards fill before your eyes and entire professions become void of workers. Pulling out of one is near impossible, but if you do it is an accomplishment worthy of song.There are however some drawbacks: 1. Gameplay is more or less managing a set of spreadsheets, drop down menus and building stuff to your best ability-then observing the outcome. 2.  Starving people will walk past barns and markets FILLED TO CAPACITY with food and starve to death on the way to their house, come on people grab a peach at the market and don't die.3. So many houses... In order to keep a population growing you constantly have to build houses leading to the before mentioned urban sprawl, eventual fire, disease, lucky tornado and/or food shortage leading to DEATH SPIRAL.4. Glitches: By scheduling to demolish and then canceling the demolish order graveyards are 'emptied' of bodies even though gravestones remain allowing infinite burials on one small patch of land (useful glitch but still a glitch), Livestock walk underwater between pens instead of taking roads, lag starts to intrude with populations over 1000 (gets bad around 1400) and Gatherers are incredibly OP compared to other starting food sources.5. Do What??? Once you have a town going you may feel a sense of emptiness at having 'conquered' the game and unless you are willing to go after the achievements that sense of pointlessness will remain. However the achievements for this game offer interesting challenges instead of the standard 'get-all-the-things' sort.So overall it is a good game but there is a steep learning curve and, unless you like to achievement hunt, limited replay value, but for all that it is an addictive game into which I have sunk dozens of hours and have a few more left in me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												An extremely enjoyable game, very nice to play when you want something calm and idyllic. My advice is to be stingy on house building; there's no need to feel bad about the kids never moving out of their parents' house. ALWAYS make sure you have more than enough food to support your population. DON'T trade away stone or iron/iron tools or your steel tools. Those are finite resources on your maps, and you always want to trade FOR them. Same goes for coal - it's not worth mining (you have to choose coal or iron, choose the latter!), because steel tools aren't as valuable as you think they are (except for if you desperately need to trade for seeds maybe) and the villagers often take the coal to heat their homes, which is a complete waste. And last but not least (this will save you a headache later) build your cemetery as big as you can, preferably as far away as you can. These are just some basic advice, there are many more tips/tutorials you can find online. The only drawback on this game is maybe not enough micro-managing, which is something I prefer in my games. Unless you build a huge metropolis, you will find you often run out of things to do other than just stalk a villager or watch the animals roam around.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Banished is a game about as oppressive and meaningless as life itself. And for that reason I would recommend it, not for its entertainment value but for the raw challenge stripped of the gilding so many other simulator games can't do without. Any moments of satisfaction you find as you struggle against nature and time to build some resemblance of a town are quickly obliterated either by the proceeding tedium of routine or the catastrophe of a town-wide fire. You spend all of your time trying to manage a continuously out of balance economy with minimal data and limited input. The lives of your citizens are woefully abstract, left for you to deduce the continuity of their mundune yet often incestuous dealings. The player becomes like a god, conversely irritated and amused at the incompetence of these vain mortals.In this respect Banished can be refreshingly cruel. It seems out of place in an age that values progress, self-sustaining systems, rewards for investment. The game is still compelling even though it rewards strife with more strife rather than superficial celebration in badges, thumbs-up, and other trinkets of gameification. The player's struggle is not for the carrot-on-a-stick of clearly defined objectives. It's tragic pathos all the way down. You find yourself struggling against both  your own intuitions, the lack of direction, and the permanent imbalance of the game's mechanics, such that the only "victory" possible is, like the live's of the people you lead in futility, a noble and heroic stand in the face of an inevitable downfall.Simply put, if you want the control of a SimCity or the personal interest of a Harvest Moon, don't buy it. Banished is heartless, even if it is still lovable.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Banished has a level of detail that is not achieved in many city building simulators.  Unfortunately there is no technology progression like there is in Sim City or other games.  All buildings can be built straight away, with no unlocks after certain milestones or achievments, and no tech trees.  Undoubtedly though, some players will appreciate this.  That being said, there is a great deal of depth to the ways a town can be managed in this game.  Resource balance is paramount, and even the slightest changes can have significant effects in both the short and long term.  This requires an attention to detail by the palyer that I thoroughly enjoy.  The underlying mechanics in Bansihed are impressive considereing some games like Sim City and Cities XL can drive a player mad when it screws up seemingly simple mechanics like traffic flow. I have not experienced such frustration with Banished.  Citizens will actually move as close as possible to their work place.  And even as the town's population grows, the underlying mechanics don't get all screwed up like I experience in Sim City for years.I definitely recommend this game.

												Banished is a town building game done right. Its everything you could want in a town building and survival game with a simple goal: Survive. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												Banished has a ton going for it, without the need for enemies. The weather, food and population will keep you busy micromanaging that you wouldn't want to add enemies on top of it. My first few play attempts I got "rek'd" real good, the furthest I made it was 23 years before the entire population ran out of tools.......Not something you'd think would make/break a community of roughly 200 people, but boy did it. No tools? Then you can't make jack #%$@! Tools are required to build, harvest, or even make more tools! Its small things like this that make Banished so unique in this genre. For me, when playing Age of Empires, I'd create an awesome looking town/city/village and then BAM attacked by a whole hoard of an army. Meanwhile I'm sitting at like 50 military, and then you get demolished. All that beautiful town planning put to waste, well in Banished that's the key to it all. If you take your time, plan each move and GROW SLOWLY then you'll see that Banished is quite rewarding. If you're a fast paced RTS kind of person though, this isn't for you. The game has the ability to speed up production time and overall game speed, however I don't recommend going passed x2. Why? Its not like anyone is going to come with an unstoppable hoard and destroy you right? True, but mother nature doesn't need an army to decimate you, just some snow, and uneducated people and you're SOL. That's right education also plays a huge factor in this game, if you have stupid citizens, you can expect them to produce significantly less than those who are educated. Again, if you like micromanaging, great music, and a overall relaxing town/city builder, then Banished is for you..

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
Banished KFVG ReviewThe GameBanished is a city building simulation game with resource and population management. The game is a set in a randomly generated map and you are given survivors who have been exiled from the mainland to fend for themselves.Pros Quick to understand gameplay Great AI Seasons make the game feel more alive along with the aging system Allows for different options making a town, such as having a fishing village or a town based on trade alone Steam Workshop mods and Dev modkit is constantly adding to the gameCons Game has no story or objectives and apart from different difficulties you will need to install mods to get true replayabilirt from the game  Options for specialized and private stockpiles without mods would be a welcome changeShould you buy it?In a word, yes. Banished, although lacking in objective based gameplay and having a low replayability value without dipping into the steam workshop, is a fantastic city builder which has you taking an interest in the indiviual lives of your settlers.I had a settler named Jenser, he left home and lived on his own at the tender age of 12, he became a lonely hunter out in the woods, getting venison and leather for my then small community, he lived from 12-48 all on his own until he finally got a lovely wife Linda, she was the town tailor. They had a child called Owen who later became a hunter, just like his Dad.These kinds of stories are ones I'm constantly seeing in this game and I'll continue to play it and hope for future updates to expand on the game and maybe even give it a grand objective.So yes, get Banished.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												A timesuck if there ever was one. I've spent days on one village and restarted others several times. There are quite a few guides online to give a few tips (like best sizes for farm and livestock pens) to make the game easier but it tends to boil down to waiting a while for your villagers to do things. For example, the school is important for better workers but it adds a few years onto actually having the workers. You don't interact much with them other then assigning jobs. You can set limits on food production, movement of goods and trading but most of that can be automated. It is very much a 'build this here, gather that there and work in this building' and let the villagers run amok type of game.If you enjoy city building then this game is definitely worth the $20 price. Still, there is nothing like watching a starving villager pick up food, only to walk a few paces and drop it then run between the food and the barn repeatedly until they die.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												This is a very solid singleplayer city-builder. I have not played many other city builders simply because the blocky graphics (who wants to build something if it's going to make their eyes hurt?), or way too intensive micromanaging turned me off.This game is simple. This game is easy. This game is elegant with a beautiful soundtrack. That is until a single fire ravages through your urban center destroying any sense of unity your village had. Then---DEATH SPIRAL. Death spirals are so intense, as you watch graveyards fill before your eyes and entire professions become void of workers. Pulling out of one is near impossible, but if you do it is an accomplishment worthy of song.There are however some drawbacks: 1. Gameplay is more or less managing a set of spreadsheets, drop down menus and building stuff to your best ability-then observing the outcome. 2.  Starving people will walk past barns and markets FILLED TO CAPACITY with food and starve to death on the way to their house, come on people grab a peach at the market and don't die.3. So many houses... In order to keep a population growing you constantly have to build houses leading to the before mentioned urban sprawl, eventual fire, disease, lucky tornado and/or food shortage leading to DEATH SPIRAL.4. Glitches: By scheduling to demolish and then canceling the demolish order graveyards are 'emptied' of bodies even though gravestones remain allowing infinite burials on one small patch of land (useful glitch but still a glitch), Livestock walk underwater between pens instead of taking roads, lag starts to intrude with populations over 1000 (gets bad around 1400) and Gatherers are incredibly OP compared to other starting food sources.5. Do What??? Once you have a town going you may feel a sense of emptiness at having 'conquered' the game and unless you are willing to go after the achievements that sense of pointlessness will remain. However the achievements for this game offer interesting challenges instead of the standard 'get-all-the-things' sort.So overall it is a good game but there is a steep learning curve and, unless you like to achievement hunt, limited replay value, but for all that it is an addictive game into which I have sunk dozens of hours and have a few more left in me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
Pros: A refreshing take on the city sim genreA fun challenge, difficult to masterLightweight game that works on my old laptop144hz supportSolid game, no bugs encounteredCons: No steam cloud support for savesThe game is hard to learn, I found myself googling a lotGraphics and sound are lackingThoughtsFirst time I ran Banished I was overwhelmed, my whole town died off, nothing worked right.  I came back to it months later and only fared slightly better.  I started hitting up Reddit everytime I ran into a problem and now I am starting to learn the game.  The game is brutally hard for me.  But that's sort of the point, the odds are stacked against your banished citizens.  This isn't Sim City where you just zone large swaths of land and things will largley sort themselves out to some degree; even if you do end up a simulation of Detroit.  In this game your whole town will die if you don't micromanage all the rescources.  But its very rewarding to have a stockpile of food and firewood ready for winter.  The graphics aren't anything to brag about - but on the flipside the game supports 144hz, it can also run on an old i5 dual core laptop, and it takes up less than 300mb of space.  The sound ins't great, but it gets the job done.  I didn't care for the constant rain, but the effect can be disabled.

												This game is an amazing medieval city sim builder. You will have fun, success and then failure. It is a fun and rewarding experience if you can pull off a successful town. That said though, I have had 3 villages that have had 300 citizens and almost 100 years in each one. When this happens there is not much more you can do after that except expand, and that is all you can do. This can get very repetitive and boring. I hope the developer ( and there is only one developer) has time to add more content for the end game. Putting that aside, Great Game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												So, I really don't know why it's taken me so long to write a review for this game, but here goes!I can give you 100 reasons why you should get this game, and only one why you shouldn't.If you're looking for a war/fighting game, move on. This game is a beautifully crafted true town builder, and everything I've ever wanted from a game like this.Think Age Of Empires, except when you've built your meticulously planned settlement you don't get a load of enemies coming and burning it all down. You can choose exactly where everything goes, and you really have to think about the lay-out and planning of your town to make it as effeciant and seamless as possible.I've been playing this since before all the workshop mods, and even then it was a great game. But now with the inclusion of user-created and dev created mods it's just a work of art. The crafting ladders are now massive, and you can happily run a small village or expand into a heavy working production town. You can choose to lay out your houses in beautiful hamlets, or build big and close together for the real medievil city feel.As you can see from my hours, which don't include the 150+ that for some reason vanished when I transferred my account some time ago, I have played this and loved every second of it. Taking your small band of villagers from a group of 20 to a booming town of 500 is amazing but challenging and it really keeps you on your toes for foward planning.Oh, and we can't forget the naming system. Probably the best thing about the entire game!TD;DR - Just get this game :)
